revision.text:
[[Image:Continental Orgs Map.png|350px|right|thumb|Organizations grouping almost all the countries in their respective continents. Note that [[Russia]] and [[Turkey]] are members of both the [[Council of Europe]] (CoE) and the [[Asia Cooperation Dialogue]] (ACD). See also: [[international organization]].]] [[Image:Regional Organizations Map.png|350px|right|thumb|Several smaller regional organizations with non-overlapping memberships.]] [[Image:Alliances expansive Map.png|350px|right|thumb|Several non-overlapping large alliances. Softer colours indicate observer/associate or candidate countries.]]
'''Regional organizations''' ('''ROs''') are, in a sense, [[international organization]]s (IOs), as they incorporate international membership and encompass [[Geopolitics|geopolitical]] entities that operationally transcend a single [[nation state]]. However, their membership is characterized by boundaries and demarcations characteristic to a defined and unique geography, such as continents, or geopolitics, such as [[trade bloc|economic blocs]]. They have been established to foster cooperation and political and economic integration or dialogue among states or entities within a restrictive geographical or geopolitical boundary. They both reflect common patterns of development and history that have been fostered since the end of [[World War II]] as well as the fragmentation inherent in [[globalization]]. Most ROs tend to work alongside well-established multilateral organizations such as the [[United Nations]].<ref>United Nations. "Cooperation with regional organizations", in ''Annual Report of the Secretary-General on the work of the Organization 1995'', ch. 4</ref> While in many instances a regional organization is simply referred to as an international organization, in many others it makes sense to use the term ''regional organization'' to stress the more limited scope of a particular membership.
Examples of ROs include, a.o., the<!--alphabetically--> [[African Union]] (AU), [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations]] (ASEAN), [[Arab League]] (AL), [[Caribbean Community]] (CARICOM), [[Council of Europe]] (CoE), [[Eurasian Economic Union]] (EEU), [[European Union]] (EU), [[South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation]] (SAARC), [[Union for the Mediterranean]] (UfM), [[Union of South American Nations]] (USAN).
== See also == * [[International organization]] * [[List of intergovernmental organizations]] * [[List of regional organizations by population]] * [[List of trade blocs]] * [[Regional Economic Communities]] * [[Regional integration]] * [[Supranational union]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading== * Rodrigo Tavares (2009), ''Regional Security: The Capacity of International Organizations''. London and New York: Routledge.
{{portalbar|Business and economics}} {{Regional organizations}} {{International power}}

'''[[International Call Prefix]]: 00''' ==Calling formats== To call in Greenland, the following format is used: '''yy xx xx''' Calls inside Greenland '''+299 yy xx xx''' Calls from outside Greenland '''00''' International Direct Dialing code ==List of area codes in Greenland== {| class="wikitable" border=1 !colspan="2"|LIST OF AREA CODEShttp://www.itu.int/oth/T0202000056/en |- !Area Code !Area/City |- |31 XX XX ||Nuuk |- |32 XX XX ||Nuuk |- |33 XX XX ||Nuuk |- |34 XX XX ||Nuuk |- |35 XX XX ||Nuuk |- |36 XX XX ||Nuuk |- |61 XX XX ||Nanortalik |- |64 XX XX ||Qaqortoq |- |66 XX XX ||Narsaq |- |68 XX XX ||Paamiut |- |69 1X XX ||Ivittuut |- |81 XX XX ||Maniitsoq |- |84 XX XX ||Kangerlussuaq |- |85 XX XX ||Sisimiut |- |86 XX XX ||Sisimiut |- |87 XX XX ||Kangaatsiaq |- |89 XX XX ||Aasiaat |- |91 XX XX ||Qasigiannguit |- |92 XX XX ||Qeqertarsuaq |- |94 XX XX ||Ilulissat |- |95 XX XX ||Uummannaq |- |96 XX XX ||Upernavik |- |97 XX XX ||Qaanaaq |- |98 XX XX ||Tasiilaq |- |99 XX XX ||Ittoqqortoormiit |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *https://travel.state.gov/travel/cis_pa_tw/cis/cis_1100.html *https://web.archive.org/web/20090201120828/http://denmark.usembassy.gov/living-in-denmark.html {{North America topic|Telephone numbers in}} [[Category:Telephone numbers by country|Greenland]] [[Category:Communications in Greenland]] {{Greenland-stub}} {{Telephonenumber-stub}}

{{split portions|Timeline of Dominican Republic|date=June 2017}} The following is a timeline of the [[Santo Domingo#History|history]] of the city of [[Santo Domingo]] in the [[Dominican Republic]]. {{Dynamic list}} {{TOC right}}
==16th century==
* 1492- First Viceroyalty in the [[New World]] is established in Santo Domingo ([[Columbian Viceroyalty|Viceroyalty of the Indies]]) * 1496 - [[Captaincy General of Santo Domingo|Spanish colony of Santo Domingo]], first colony in the New World, is established.<ref name="bbc-timeline">{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-19343656 |title=Dominican Republic Profile: Timeline |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=April 30, 2014 }}</ref> * 1501- {{illm|Calle Las Damas|es}}, first street in the New World, is constructed * 1502- Santo Domingo becomes the home of all the future [[conquistador]]s ([[Hernán Cortés|Hernan Cortes]], [[Francisco Pizarro]], [[Vasco Núñez de Balboa]]'','' [[Alonso de Ojeda]], [[Pedro Menéndez de Avilés]]'','' [[Diego Velázquez de Cuéllar]]'','' [[Juan Ponce de León]], [[Rodrigo de Bastidas]], [[Pedro de Alvarado]], [[Lucas Vázquez de Ayllón]], among others) * 1503- Santo Domingo becomes the official headquarters for the exploration and [[Conquest of the Americas|conquest of the New World]] * 1503- [[Casa de Contratación|Casa de Contratacion]] is created in Sevilla to regulate trade with the Americas * 1505 - [[Fortaleza Ozama]], first fortress in the Americas, is built. * 1509- [[Reales Atarazanas (Santo Domingo)|Reales Atarazanas]], first warehouse complex in the New World, is built * 1510- {{illm|Iglesia y Convento de los Dominicos|es|lt=Church of the Convent of the Dominican Order}}, first church in the New World, is built * 1511 ** [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Santo Domingo|Roman Catholic diocese of Santo Domingo]] established.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chronology of Catholic Dioceses: Dominican Republic |url= http://www.katolsk.no/organisasjon/verden/chronology/dominican_rep|publisher=[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Oslo]] |location=Norway |accessdate= 23 January 2017 }}</ref> ** [[Alcázar de Colón]] (Columbus Alcazar), first castle or viceroyal residence in the Americas, is built ** [[Real Audiencia of Santo Domingo|The Royal Audiencia of Santo Domingo]], first [[court]] in the New World, is established * 1513- [[Laws of Burgos]] are passed concerning the treatment of the indigenous people. * 1514 - [[María de Toledo|Maria de Toledo]], serve as regent of the colony during the absence of her spouse the governor until 1520. * 1522- [[Jean Fleury]] commits the first recorded attack of piracy against Spanish ships * 1538 - [[Universidad Santo Tomás de Aquino|Universidad de Santo Tomas de Aquino]], first university in the New World, is founded.<ref name="Figueredo2007">{{cite book|author=D. H. Figueredo|title=Latino Chronology |series= Chronologies of the American Mosaic |year=2007|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-34154-0}}</ref> * 1539- Santo Domingo is named the ''"Athens of the New World"'';{{sfn|Hazard|1873}} Intellectuals such as [[Gonzalo Fernández de Oviedo y Valdés|Gonzalo Fernández de Oviedo]], [[:es:Ramón_Pané|Ramón Pané]], [[Bernardo Buil]], [[Bartolomé de las Casas|Bartolome de las Casas]], [[Pedro de Córdoba|Pedro de Cordoba]] and [[Antonio de Montesinos]] reside in the island and write their works there. Later figures like humanist [[Alessandro Geraldini]], writer [[Girolamo Benzoni|Gerolamo Benzoni]], poets [[:es:Juan_de_Castellanos|Juan de Castellanos]] and [[:es:Eugenio_de_Salazar|Eugenio de Salazar]], medical authors [[:es:Diego_Álvarez_Chanca|Diego Álvarez Chanca]] and [[Juan Mendez Nieto]], and dramatists [[Tirso de Molina]] and [[:es:Miguel_de_Carvajal|Micael de Carvajal]] reside there as well. * 1540 - [[Basilica Cathedral of Santa María la Menor|Cathedral Primate of the Americas]], first cathedral in the Americas, is built.<ref name=verill-1914>{{Citation |publisher = Dodd, Mead |publication-place = New York |author = A. Hyatt Verrill |title = Porto Rico past and present and San Domingo of today |publication-date = 1914 |url= https://archive.org/stream/portoricopastpre00verr }}</ref> * 1543 - [[Puerta del Conde|Fort San Genaro]], today La Puerta del Conde (The Count's Gate), construction begins. * 1552 - [[Hospital San Nicolás de Bari]], first hospital in the Americas, is built. * 1574- [[Francisco Tostado de la Peña]], [[Elvira de Mendoza]] and [[Leonor de Ovando]] write the first sonnets in the New World{{Relevance inline|date=January 2017}} * 1586- [[Francis Drake]] captures Santo Domingo in the [[Battle of Santo Domingo (1586)|Battle of Santo Domingo]] * 1588- [[:es:Cristóbal de Llerena|Cristobal de Llerena]] writes the first theatrical play in the New World{{Relevance inline|date=January 2017}} * 1600- After the gold mines were exhausted most colonists had decided to become conquistadors and explorers and had left for the mines of [[Mexico]] and [[Peru]]. Others decide to settle and become hateros (herders), farmers and merchants.
== 17th century ==
* 1602- Colony of Santo Domingo is bypassed by immigrants from Spain and enters decline due to depopulation * 1605- [[:es:Devastaciones de Osorio|Devastaciones de Osorio]] take place in the North Coast to prevent illicit trade with colonies other than Spain * 1620- The [[Brethren of the Coast|Brotherhood of the Coast]] is formed by pirates in the [[Tortuga (Haiti)|Tortuga island]] * 1630- The fight against the [[Buccaneer|buccaneers]] and [[Filibuster (military)|filibusters]] begins ([[Piracy in the Caribbean]]){{Relevance inline|date=January 2017}} * 1654- [[Capture of Fort Rocher]]- The Spaniards capture the [[Tortuga (Haiti)|Tortuga Island]] from the French for the 4th and last time. * 1655- [[Siege of Santo Domingo (1655)|English invasion of Penn and Venables]] is defeated by the criollos * 1691- [[Battle of Sabana Real]] is won against the French * 1697 - Island of [[Hispaniola]] divided into Spanish [[Captaincy General of Santo Domingo|Santo Domingo]] and French [[Saint-Domingue]] ([[Haiti]]) per [[Treaty of Ryswick]] that settled the [[Nine Years' War|Nine Year's War]].<ref name="bbc-timeline" />
== 18th Century == * 1716- [[Privateer#Spain and its colonies|Privateers]] corsairs from the colony of Santo Domingo take action during the [[Piracy in the Caribbean#Golden Age of Piracy.2C 1660.E2.80.931726|Golden Age of Piracy]] * 1724- [http://www.discoversea.com/The-Quicksilver-Galleons.html Guadalupe and Tolosa Shipwreck] in [[Samaná (town)|Samana]] * 1741- [[Battle of Cartagena de Indias]]- Santo Domingo participates in the Spanish victory against the English Navy * 1760- Population is bolstered by immigration from the [[Canary Islands]] resettling the northern part of the island. Population grows from 6,000 to 125,000 by 1790. * 1775- [[Saint-Domingue]] becomes one of the richest colonies in the world in the 18th-century [[French colonial empire|French empire]]{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} * 1791- [[Haitian Revolution]] takes place in Saint-Domingue * 1795 - [[Era de Francia]] begins after the [[Treaty of Basel (1795)|Treaty of Basel]] where Spain ceded the eastern two-thirds of the island of [[Hispaniola]] to France in exchange for keeping [[Gipuzkoa]], ending the [[War of the Pyrenees]]. * 1796- Massive emigration of the colonial families to Cuba, Venezuela, Puerto Rico and Mexico where they become cultural pioneers and intellectual figures<ref name="bbc-timeline" /> Famous figures and descendants of the Treaty of Basel diaspora include [[José María Heredia y Heredia|Jose Maria Heredia]], [[Severiano de Heredia]], [[José-Maria de Heredia|Jose-Maria de Heredia Girard]], [[Domingo del Monte]], [http://www.encaribe.org/es/article/esteban-pichardo-tapia/1567 Esteban Pichardo], [[Campuzano Polanco family#Francisco Javier Caro .28Santo Domingo.2C 1773- Madrid.2C 1848.29|Francisco Javier Caro]], [[:es:Francisco Javier Angulo Guridi|Angulo Guridi]] brothers, [[:es:Jacobo de Villaurrutia|Jacobo de Villaurrutia]], [[Juan Vicente Moscoso]], [[Manuel Márquez Sterling]], [[Rafael María Baralt|Rafael Maria Baralt]], [[:es:Arístides Rojas|Arístides Rojas Espaillat]], [[Francisco Javier Foxa y Lecande|Francisco Javier Foxa]], [[Emilio Portes Gil]], Antonio Melendez Bazan, [http://www.encaribe.org/es/article/pedro-agustin-morell-de-santa-cruz/906 Pedro Agustin Morel de Santa Cruz], Antonio del Monte y Tejada, [http://www.encaribe.org/es/article/andres-lopez-de-medrano/737 Andres Lopez Medrano], [[Ramón Emeterio Betances|Ramon Emeterio Betances]], [http://clio.academiahistoria.org.do/trabajos/clio93/Clio_1952_No_93-06.pdf Raimundo Rendon Sarmiento]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}, [[Eugenio María de Hostos|Eugenio Maria de Hostos]], [[Máximo Gómez]], [[Antonio Maceo Grajales|Antonio Maceo]], among others. * 1797- The [[Universidad Santo Tomás de Aquino|University of Santo Tomas de Aquino]] closes which, along with the emigration of the intellectual class, causes a big "brain drain"{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
==19th century== * 1808- [[Battle of Palo Hincado]]. Criollos from the Island beat the French [[Napoleonic Wars|Napoleonic troops]] and make Santo Domingo a Spanish colony again. * 1809 - 2nd Spanish colony or [[España Boba]] ("Foolish Spain") after [[Spanish reconquest of Santo Domingo|La Reconquista]] takes place.<ref name="bbc-timeline" /> * 1821- [[Republic of Spanish Haiti|Ephemeral Independence]] from Spain takes place * 1822 - [[Unification of Hispaniola|Unification of the island]]. Haitians in power. Further emigration takes place<ref name="bbc-timeline" /> * 1838- [[La Trinitaria (Dominican Republic)|La Trinitaria]] is created * 1844- [[Dominican War of Independence|Dominican War of Independence from Haiti]] starts * February: [[La Trinitaria (Dominican Republic)|La Trinitaria]] take Ozama Fortress. * July: [[Pedro Santana]] in power.{{sfn|Marley|2005}} * City becomes capital of newly independent [[Dominican Republic]] * 1845- [[:es:José María Serra de Castro|El Dominicano]], first political newspaper, begins circulation *1854- First cultural society "[[Jose Gabriel García#Writing|Los Amantes de las Letras]]" ("Lovers of the Letters") is created{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} *1854- First cultural newspapers El Progreso and [[Jose Gabriel García#Writing|El Oasis]] appear{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} *1860- First Dominican theater is established by society "Los Amantes de las Letras"{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} * 1861 - [[Spanish occupation of the Dominican Republic|3rd Spanish Colony]] begins to prevent further Haitian occupation. Spanish in power again.{{sfn|Marley|2005}} * 1862- First printing press company, [[Jose Gabriel García#Printing and Publishing Company Garc.C3.ADa Hermanos|Garcia Hermanos]], is established * 1863- [[Dominican Restoration War|Dominican-Spanish War (1863-1865)]] also known as the [[Dominican Restoration War]] begins * 1865- 2nd Republic begins * 1866- The University [[Universidad Autónoma de Santo Domingo|Instituto Profesional]] (later [[Universidad Autónoma de Santo Domingo|University of Santo Domingo]]) is established * 1875- [[Sugar cane mill|Sugar mills]] emerge and urban development takes place * 1889 - ''[[Listín Diario]]'' newspaper begins publication.<ref name="europa2003">{{cite book |title=Europa World Year Book 2003 |year=2003|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-85743-227-5 |chapter=Dominican Republic |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=XLvU9lroRuUC&pg=PA1441 }}</ref>
==20th century==
* 1907 - [[Tigres del Licey|Licey]] baseball club formed.<ref name=Ruck1999>{{cite book|author=Rob Ruck |title=The Tropic of Baseball: Baseball in the Dominican Republic |year=1999|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|isbn=0-8032-8978-2}}</ref> * 1914 - El Placer de los Estudios built.{{sfn|Uribe|2010}} * 1916 - [[United States occupation of the Dominican Republic (1916–24)|United States occupation of the Dominican Republic]] begins. * 1921 - [[Leones del Escogido|Escogido]] baseball club formed.<ref name=Ruck1999 /> * 1924 - [[United States occupation of the Dominican Republic (1916–24)|United States occupation of the Dominican Republic]] ends. * 1930 - September: [[1930 Dominican Republic hurricane|Hurricane San Zenon]].<ref name=Derby2009 /> * 1930- [[Rafael Trujillo|Era of Trujillo]] begins * 1935 - Population: 71,297.{{sfn|Marley|2005}} * 1936 ** City renamed "Trujillo City".{{sfn|Marley|2005}} ** Colombina avenue built.{{sfn|Uribe|2010}} * 1938 - Breakwater built in harbour.{{sfn|Marley|2005}} * 1941 - La Jaragua hotel built.<ref name="Segre2003">{{cite book|author=Roberto Segre|title=Arquitectura antillana del siglo XX |year=2003|publisher=Editorial Arte y Literature |location=Havana |isbn=978-959-03-0129-2 |language=Spanish }}</ref> * 1942 - [[:es:Escuela Nacional de Artes Visuales|National School of Fine Arts]] and Teatro Olimpia (cinema)<ref name=CinemaTreasures>{{cite web |url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/dominican-republic/santo-domingo?status=all |title= Movie Theaters in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic |work=CinemaTreasures.org |publisher= Cinema Treasures LLC |location=Los Angeles |accessdate=April 30, 2014 }}</ref> open. * 1944 - [[National Palace (Dominican Republic)|National Palace]] built. * 1948 - ''El Caribe'' [[List of newspapers in the Dominican Republic|newspaper]] in publication.<ref name=worldcat>{{cite web |url= http://www.worldcat.org/search?q=su%3ASanto+Domingo+%28Dominican+Republic%29+Newspapers.&qt=hot_subject |title=Santo Domingo (Dominican Republic) Newspapers |location=USA |work=WorldCat |publisher=[[Online Computer Library Center]] |accessdate=April 30, 2014 }}</ref> * 1950 - Population: 181,553.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/products/dyb/1950_round.htm |work=Demographic Yearbook 1955 |year= |publisher=[[Statistical Office of the United Nations]] |location=New York |title=Population of capital city and cities of 100,000 or more inhabitants }}</ref> * 1953 - [[San Isidro Air Base|Base Aérea Trujillo]] (airbase) in operation near city. * 1955 ** December: [[Fair of Peace and Fraternity of the Free World]] opens.<ref name=Derby2009>{{cite book|author=Lauren H. Derby|title=The Dictator’s Seduction: Politics and the Popular Imagination in the Era of Trujillo |year= 2009|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=0-8223-9086-8}}</ref> ** [[Estadio Quisqueya]] (baseball stadium) opens. * 1956 - [[National Pantheon of the Dominican Republic]] (mausoleum) established. * 1961 - May 30: [[Rafael Trujillo|Trujillo]] assassinated near city. * 1961- November 19: [[:es:Rebelión de los Pilotos|Rebellion of the Pilots]]. Trujillo family flees the country * 1965 ** April 24: [[Dominican Civil War]] ** April 28: [[United States occupation of the Dominican Republic (1965–66)|United States occupation of the Dominican Republic]] begins. * 1966 ** July 1: [[United States occupation of the Dominican Republic (1965–66)|United States occupation of the Dominican Republic]] ends. ** ''[[El Nacional (Santo Domingo)|El Nacional]]'' newspaper begins publication.<ref name=europa2003 /> * 1970 - Population: 673,470 city; 817,645 urban agglomeration.<ref>{{cite book |url= https://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/products/dyb/1980_round.htm |title=1985 Demographic Yearbook |year=1987 |author=[[United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs]], Statistical Office |location=New York |chapter=Population of capital cities and cities of 100,000 and more inhabitants |pages=247-289 }}</ref> * 1972 - [[Instituto Tecnológico de Santo Domingo|Santo Domingo Institute of Technology]] founded. * 1973 - [[Museo de las Casas Reales]] (museum) established. * 1974 ** City hosts [[1974 Central American and Caribbean Games]]. ** [[Estadio Olímpico Félix Sánchez]], [[Palacio de los Deportes Virgilio Travieso Soto]], and [[Centro Olímpico Juan Pablo Duarte]] (sports venues) open. * 1976 - [[Dr. Rafael Ma. Moscoso National Botanical Garden|Moscoso National Botanical Garden]] founded. * 1979 - August: [[Hurricane David]].{{sfn|Marley|2005}} * 1986 - [[Latin American Social Sciences Institute]] established in city.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.flacso.org.do/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=48&Itemid=1 |title=Quienes somos? |location=Santo Domingo |language=Spanish |publisher=Facultad Latinoamericana de Ciencias Sociales - República Dominicana |accessdate=May 4, 2014 }}</ref> * 1992- [[Columbus Lighthouse|Faro a Colon]] (The [[Columbus Lighthouse]]) is erected in honor of the 500th anniversary of the [[Discovery of the Americas]] * 1993 - Population: 2,134,779.<ref>{{cite book |url= https://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/products/dyb/1990_round.htm |title=1995 Demographic Yearbook |year=1997 |author=United Nations Department for Economic and Social Information and Policy Analysis, Statistics Division |location=New York |chapter=Population of capital cities and cities of 100,000 and more inhabitants |pages=262-321 }}</ref> * 1997 - [[Internet exchange point]] installed.<ref name=anzovin2000>{{cite book |title=[[Famous First Facts]] |year=2000 |publisher= H.W. Wilson Co. |editor=Steven Anzovin and Janet Podell |isbn= 0824209583 }}</ref> * 1998 ** [[Autodrómo Internacional de Las Américas]] opens near city. ** [[Johnny Ventura]] becomes mayor.<ref>{{citation |title=Santo Domingo Journal |date=June 14, 1999 |work=New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/06/14/world/santo-domingo-journal-steeped-in-the-merengue-amway-and-now-trash.html }}</ref> * 1999 - [[Museo Bellapart]] founded.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://museobellapart.com/ |title=Museo Bellapart |language=Spanish |accessdate=May 4, 2014 }}</ref>
==21st century==
* 2001 - November 12: [[American Airlines Flight 587|Crash]] in New York of Santo Domingo-bound airplane.<ref name=bbc-timeline /> * 2002 - Roberto Salcedo becomes mayor. * 2003 ** August: City hosts [[2003 Pan American Games]]. ** [[Malecon Center|Malecon towers]] built. * 2009 - [[Santo Domingo Metro]] begins operating. * 2010 - Population: 965,040; metro 2,907,100.
==See also== * [[Santo Domingo#History|Santo Domingo history]] * [[Ciudad Colonial (Santo Domingo)]] * [[History of the Dominican Republic]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}} :''This article incorporates information from the [[Spanish Wikipedia]].''
==Bibliography== * {{Cite book|title=Santo Domingo: Past and Present, with a Glance at Hayti|last=Hazard|first=Samuel|publisher=Harper & Brothers|year=1873|isbn=|location=New York|pages=228 |ref= {{harvid|Hazard|1873}} }} * {{cite journal |title=Santo Domingo City |author= Nathan Appleton |journal= Journal of the American Geographical Society of New York |volume=23 |year=1891 |url=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/uc1.$b692729?urlappend=%3Bseq=675 }} * {{Citation |publisher = ABC-CLIO |isbn = 1576070271 |publication-place = Santa Barbara, California |title = Historic Cities of the Americas |author = David Marley |publication-date = 2005 |volume=1 |chapter=Dominican Republic: Santo Domingo |pages=91–106 |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=q1a4j2HNmjUC&pg=PA91 |ref= {{harvid|Marley|2005}} }} * {{cite book|author=Jesse Hoffnung-Garskof|title=A Tale of Two Cities: Santo Domingo and New York After 1950|year=2008|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=0-691-12338-1 }} * {{cite book|title=Caribbean Modernist Architecture|year=2010|publisher=[[University of Technology, Jamaica|UTech Jamaica]] and Museum of Modern Art|isbn=978-0-87070-775-9 |series=Archivos de Arquitectura Antillana |chapter=Setting the City in Motion: Urban Landscape and Modernity in Santo Domingo |author= Marcos Barinas Uribe |chapterurl= https://books.google.com/books?id=CgI9cMHsSPIC&pg=PA22 |ref= {{harvid|Uribe|2010}} }}
==External links== {{Commons category|Santo Domingo Province}} * Digital Public Library of America. [http://dp.la/search?page_size=100&q=%22Santo+Domingo%22+%22Dominican+Republic%22&utf8=✓ Items related to Santo Domingo], various dates * {{citation |author=[[Arnoldus Montanus]] |trans-title=The New and Unknown World: or Description of America and the Southland |title=[[De Nieuwe en Onbekende Weereld]] |language=Dutch |location=Antwerp |publisher= J. Meurs |year = 1671 |chapter=Eiland Hispaniola |chapterurl= http://www.wdl.org/en/item/518/view/1/220/ }} (image of Urbs Domingo)

{{Infobox park | name = Tunduru Gardens
{{small|''Jardim Tunduru''}} | photo = Jardim Tunduru (4106342749).jpg | photo_width = | photo_caption = | map = | map_width = | type = [[Urban park]] | location = [[Maputo]], [[Mozambique]] | nearest_city = | coords = {{coord|-25.9716|32.5739|type:landmark_region:MZ|display=inline, title}} | area = | created = 1885 | operator = | visitation_num = | status = | designation = | open = }} The '''Tunduru Gardens''' is public park and garden in downtown [[Maputo]], [[Mozambique]]. It was designed in 1885 by [[United Kingdom|British]] gardener [[Thomas Honney]]. It is home to tennis courts owned by the [[Mozambique Tennis Federation]].{{cite book|title=Mozambique|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_G1-nXEv7REC&pg=PA63|year=2010|publisher=Lonely Planet|isbn=978-1-74104-888-9|pages=63}}[http://www.timeout.co.mz/maputo/downtown.htm Downtown Maputo] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20010308224600/http://www.timeout.co.mz/maputo/downtown.htm |date=2001-03-08 }} timeout.co.mz ==References== {{Sister project links | commons = Category:Jardim Tunduru |wikt=no | q=no| b=no | n=no |s=no | v=no | voy=no | species=no |d=Q7852917| display=Tunduru Gardens}} {{reflist}} [[Category:Parks in Mozambique]] [[Category:Geography of Maputo]] [[Category:Urban public parks]] [[Category:Sport in Mozambique]] [[Category:Sport in Maputo]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Maputo]] {{Mozambique-geo-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Designation list | designation1 = Ramsar | designation1_offname = Vallée de la Haute-Sûre | designation1_date = 8 March 2004 | designation1_number = 1408<ref>{{Cite web|title=Vallée de la Haute-Sûre|website=[[Ramsar Convention|Ramsar]] Sites Information Service|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/1408|accessdate=25 April 2018}}</ref>}} The '''Upper Sûre Natural Park''' ({{lang-lb|Naturpark Uewersauer}}, {{lang-fr|Parc Naturel de la Haute-Sûre}}, {{lang-de|Naturpark Obersauer}}) is a national park in north-western [[Luxembourg]]. Located in the [[Oesling]] region, the park is primarily an area of conservation and a specially protected area for wild birds.
At the heart of the park is the [[Upper Sûre Lake]], the largest area of water in Luxembourg.
==Objectives== The objectives of the park are threefold: *To protect the natural environment and ecosystem. The main principle underlying ecosystem protection in the park is that the environment is an integral network in which each element interacts and affects the functioning of the while. This means preserving the indigenous flora and fauna as well as protecting the purity of air, water, and soil quality. *To develop economic activity, mostly forestry and low-density tourism as a means of creating employment and a high quality life. As a result, the transportation infrastructure throughout the park is excellent. To achieve this, the park provides a host of leisure activities, from nature walks to tours of cultural monuments, to water sports on the Upper Sûre Lake. More than {{convert|500|km|mi}} of well maintained footpaths make this a popular spot for day trippers and a wide range of accommodation for the vacationer. A fair and festival is held in the park annually on the first weekend in July. *To preserve the [[architecture|architectural]] heritage of the area, which ranges from large numbers of [[chapel]]s and disused mills to former slate [[quarry|quarries]] and castle ruins.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{de icon}} [http://www.naturpark-sure.lu/ Official website of the Upper Sûre Natural Park] *[http://ec.europa.eu/enterprise/sectors/tourism/eden/themes-destinations/countries/luxembourg/the-nature-park-of-the-upper-sure Awarded "EDEN - European Destinations of Excellence" non traditional tourist destination 2010]

{{About|the unrecognised state in Myanmar (Burma)|the historical region|Wa States}} {{Distinguish|Wa (Japan)|Washington (state)|Washington State University|Western Australia}} {{EngvarB|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox country |conventional_long_name = Wa State |native_name = {{lang|prk|Mēng Vax}} |common_name = Wa State |image_flag = Flag of Wa.svg |alt_flag = A horizontal triband (blue, red, blue) with a white 9-pointed star in the center |image_coat = |alt_coat = |symbol_type = |national_motto = |national_anthem = |image_map = Wa State territory map.svg |alt_map = Projection showing Wa State in green and Myanmar (Burma) in dark grey |map_caption = Wa State, as claimed by the UWSA (green),
within Myanmar (dark grey). |capital = [[Pangkham]] |coordinates = {{Coord|22|10|N|99|11|E|type:city}} |largest_city = [[Pangkham]] |official_languages = |national_languages = |regional_languages = * [[Wa language|Wa]] * [[Southwestern Mandarin|Southwestern Mandarin-Chinese]] |languages_type = Spoken languages |languages = {{flatlist| * [[Wa language|Wa]] * [[Southwestern Mandarin|Southwestern Mandarin-Chinese]] }} |ethnic_groups = |ethnic_groups_year = |demonym = |government_type = [[One-party state|One-party rule]] |leader_title1 = [[President]] |leader_name1 = [[Bao Youxiang]] (Tax Log Pang){{cite web |url = http://www.shanland.org/politics/2006/News-08180406/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131013221841/http://www.shanland.org/politics/2006/News-08180406/ |archivedate=2013-10-13 |df= }} Quote: ''"Officially, Bao Youxiang is still the President of the Wa State Government and Commander-in-Chief of the United Wa State Army," said a Thai security officer, a ten-year veteran on the Thai-Burma border'' |leader_title2 = [[Vice President]] |leader_name2 = Xiao Minliang{{cite web |url = http://democracyforburma.wordpress.com/2011/09/29/a-united-wa-state-army-uwsa-delegation-led-by-vice-president-xiao-minliang-bao-youliang-and-zhao-guo-ang-left-panghsang-for-lashio-today/ |title = A United Wa State Army (UWSA) delegation led by Vice President Xiao Minliang, Bao Youliang and Zhao Guo-ang left Panghsang for Lashio today |work = democracy for Burma |accessdate = 29 November 2014 }} |sovereignty_type = Independence {{nobold|from [[Myanmar]]}} |established_event1 = Declared |established_date1 = 17 April 1989 |established_event2 = Officially administrated as the [[Wa Self-Administered Division]] |established_date2 = 20 August 2010 |established_event3 = Recognition |established_date3 = [[Diplomatic recognition|Unrecognized]] |area_rank = |area_magnitude = |area_km2 = 17000 |percent_water = negligible |area_label = |area_footnote = |population_estimate = 558,000{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} |population_estimate_rank = |population_estimate_year = |population_census = |population_census_year = |population_density_km2 = 32.8 |population_density_rank = |population_density_sq_mi = 12.7 |currency = [[Renminbi]] |currency_code = |time_zone = [[Myanmar Standard Time|MMT]] |utc_offset = +06:30 |drives_on = right |calling_code = [[Telephone numbers in Myanmar|+95]] 73 }} '''Wa State''' ([[Wa language|Wa]]: ''Mēng Vax'' or ''Meung Va''; {{zh |c = 佤邦 |p = Wǎ Bāng }}; [[Burmese language|Burmese]]: {{lang|my|ဝပြည်နယ်}}) is an unrecognised state in [[Myanmar]] (Burma) that is currently subsumed under the official '''Wa Special Region 2''' of northern [[Shan State]].2004-12-29, [http://www.phoenixtv.com/phoenixtv/76575495906394112/20041229/477702.shtml 佤帮双雄], [[Phoenix TV]][http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,397549,00.html Soldiers of Fortune], Time Magazine. '''Quote:''' ''In return for keeping the peace, the UWSA was given full autonomy over what the regime termed "Special Region No. 2," which Bao christened "Wa state."'' The administrative capital is [[Pangkham]] ({{zh |c = 邦康 |p = Bāngkāng }}, formerly known as Panghsang, 邦桑). The name ''Wa'' derives from the [[Wa people|Wa ethnic group]], who speak a language in the [[Austroasiatic languages|Austroasiatic]] family of languages. Many of the Wa are [[animist]]s, and a small proportion of the population follows a derivative of either [[Buddhism]] or [[Christianity]]. The Wa were once known as the "Wild Wa" by the British due to their practice of [[headhunting]].[https://www.reuters.com/article/2007/09/10/idUSBKK83023 "Headhunting days are over for Myanmar's "Wild Wa"", Reuters, Sep 10, 2007.] == Politics and society == {{See also|United Wa State Party}} Wa State is divided into northern and southern regions which are separated from one another, with the {{convert|13000|sqkm|abbr=on}} southern region bordering Thailand and consisting of 200,000 people. The total area of the region controlled by the Wa State is {{convert|17000|sqkm|abbr=on}}. Political leaders of the Wa State are mostly ethnic [[Wa people]]. The government of the Wa State emulates many political features of the government of [[China]], having a Central Committee and a central party known as the United Wa State Party. Whilst the Wa State is ''de facto'' highly autonomous from the control of the central Myanmar government,2009年9月, [http://www.ide.go.jp/Japanese/Research/Region/Asia/Radar/200909.html 不透明さ増すミャンマー情勢:2010年総選挙に向けて], IDE-JETRO2011年11月15日, [http://www.excite.co.jp/News/reviewbook/20111115/E1321281192211.html 地図にない街、ワ州潜入ルポが凄い『独裁者の教養』], エキサイトレビュー their relationship is based on peaceful coexistence and the Wa State recognises the sovereignty of the central government over all of Myanmar.2011-10-13, [http://www.jqgc.com/zgjq/18033.shtml 缅甸佤邦竟然是一个山寨版的中国], 军情观察 The working language of the Wa State government is Chinese.[http://www.stimson.org/programs/myanmar-map/ Interactive Myanmar Map], The Stimson Center[http://www.infomekong.com/peoples/wa/ Wa], Infomekong[https://web.archive.org/web/20050929165301/http://www.shanland.org/resources/bookspub/humanrights/wa/general_background_of_the_wa.htm General Background of the Wa]. '''Quote:''' ''The official languages (designated by the current UWSP administration) are Mandarin and Wa.'' [[Southwest Mandarin]] and [[Wa language|Wa]] widely spoken by the population, with the language of education being [[Standard Mandarin Chinese]]. Television broadcasts within the Wa State are broadcast in [[Standard Chinese]] and Wa. Commodities within the Wa State are brought over from China, and the [[Renminbi]] is used for exchanges. [[China Mobile]] has cellular coverage over some parts of the Wa State. == History == For a long time, headman tribes were dispersed around the Wa mountainous area, with no unified governance. During the [[Qing dynasty]], the region became separated from the tribal military control of the [[Dai people]]. [[British rule in Burma]] did not administer the Wa States[[Sir J. George Scott]], ''Burma : a handbook of practical information''. London 1906, p. and the border with China was left undefined.{{cite book|editor1=N Ganesan|editor2=Kyaw Yin Hlaing|title=''Myanmar: State, Society and Ethnicity''| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rRQa0RuucF8C&pg=PA269|date=February 1, 2007| publisher=Institute of Southeast Asian Studies|isbn=978-981-230-434-6| page=269}} From the late 1940s, during the [[Chinese Civil War]], remnants of the Chinese [[National Revolutionary Army]] retreated to territory within Burma as the communists took over mainland China. Within the mountain region [[Kuomintang]] forces of the [[:zh:泰北孤軍|Eighth Army 237 division and 26th Army 93 division]] held their position for two decades in preparation for a counterattack towards mainland China. Under pressure from the United Nations, the counterattack was cancelled and the army was recalled to northern Thailand and later back to [[Taiwan]]; however, some troops decided to remain within Burma. East of the [[Salween river]], indigenous tribal guerilla groups exercised control with the support of the Burmese Communist Party. During the 1960s, the Burmese Communist Party lost its base of operations within central Burma, and with the assistance of the Chinese communists, expanded within the border regions. Many intellectual youths from China joined the Burmese Communist Party, and these forces also absorbed many local guerillas.[http://www.wastate.com.cn/culturenewsInfo.asp?id=92 佤邦歷史], Wa State government The Burmese communists gained control over Pangkham, which became their base of operations. At the end of the 1980s, the ethnic minorities of northeast Burma became politically separated from the Burmese Communist Party. On 17 April 1989, Bao Youxiang's armed forces announced their separation from the Burmese Communist Party, and formed the United Myanmar Ethnics Party, which later became the United Wa State Party. On 18 May, the Wa State and Myanmar military junta formed a ceasefire agreement. Tensions between the central government and Wa state were heightened in 2009.[http://www.epo.de/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5385:myanmar-krieg-mit-rebellen-im-wa-staat-droht&catid=28&Itemid=70 Myanmar: Krieg mit Rebellen im Wa-Staat droht] During this time, peace initiative proposals by the Wa State were rejected by the Myanmar government.[http://www.shanland.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3000:naypyitaw-turns-down-was-latest-proposal&catid=85:politics&Itemid=266 Naypyitaw turns down Wa’s latest proposal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222015620/http://www.shanland.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3000%3Anaypyitaw-turns-down-was-latest-proposal&catid=85%3Apolitics&Itemid=266 |date=2014-02-22 }} The government warned on 27 April 2010 that the WHP program could push Myanmar and the Wa State into further conflict.[http://www.shanland.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3014:shan-rebel-leader-warns-burma-army&catid=85:politics&Itemid=266 Shan rebel leader warns Burma Army] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222015618/http://www.shanland.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3014%3Ashan-rebel-leader-warns-burma-army&catid=85%3Apolitics&Itemid=266 |date=2014-02-22 }} === Communism === After the Communist Party of Burma lost control of its bases in central Burma in the late 1960s, it re-established itself in the northeast including Wa State, with the support of [[China]]. The Wa, like other ethnic groups were fighting for autonomy from Burma, and supported the CPB. They eventually rebelled along with the Kokang against the Burmese communist leadership, which was forced into exile across the Chinese border, at the time of the [[8888 Uprising]] in mainland Burma. Following the subsequent collapse of the [[Burma Socialist Programme Party]] (BSPP) rule under [[Ne Win]] in Burma, the WNO made ceasefire and peace agreements with the new military regime, the [[State Law and Order Restoration Council]] (SLORC). == Subdivisions == Wa State comprises seven districts (townships) of what the Myanmar government officially deems as the Shan State. Internally, Wa State administers 15 districts within its territory. {{columns |colwidth = 19em |col1 = ; Kho Pang district of Shan State * Yiang Chen district * Nawi district ; Mong Mau district of Shan State * Gong Ming Shan district * Gelong Ba district ; Pang Wai district of Shan State * Kun Ma district * Wang Len district ; Man Phang district of Shan State * Lien He district |col2 = ; Nah Parn district of Shan State * Yin Pan district ; Pang Yang district of Shan State * Pang Yang district * Ting Aw district * Weng Kao district * Pangh Sang district ; Mong Yang district of Shan State * Mong Pawk district * Mong Ngen district * Hotao district }} == Geography and economy == [[File:Wa state.png|thumb|right|220px|Map of the Wa State]] The region is mainly mountainous, with deep valleys. The lowest points are approximately 600 metres above sea level, with the highest mountains over 3000 metres. Initially the Wa State was heavily reliant on opium production.[http://www.asienhaus.de/public/archiv/focus26-045.pdf Die Wa in Gefahr] (German) With Chinese assistance, there has been a move towards growing rubber and tea plantations.[http://www.burmanet.org/news/2007/02/20/xinhua-general-news-service-china-develops-more-substitute-crops-for-opium-poppy-in-bordering-countries/ "Xinhua General News Service: China develops more substitute crops for opium poppy in bordering countries"] The Wa State cultivates 220,000 acres of rubber. Due to the resettlement of residents from mountainous areas to fertile valleys,[http://www.ibiblio.org/obl/docs3/BN2005-02-25.html BURMA NACHRICHTEN 4/2005, 25. Februar] (German). '''Quote:''' "Angaben der UN-Organisation zur Drogenbekämpfung UNODC und weiterer Beobachter zufolge droht durch die Ausführung des Plans zur Eliminierung des Opiumanbaus bis 2005 eine ernste humanitäre Krise der vom Opiumanbau abhängigen Bauern." there is also cultivation of wet rice, corn and vegetables. Dozens died during the resettlement due to disease and road accidents. Wa State is economically dependent on China, which supports it financially and provides military and civilian advisors and weapons.[http://www-gatago.com/soc/culture/burma/43590401.html China remains the UWSA's sole patron and arms supplier] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120717021633/http://www-gatago.com/soc/culture/burma/43590401.html |date=2012-07-17 }}[http://www.burmanet.org/news/2006/12/13/world-politics-watch-on-myanmar-china-border-tensions-escalate-between-spdc-narco-militias-michael-black/ World Politics Watch: On Myanmar-China border, tensions escalate between SPDC, narco-militias – Michael Black] It shares 82 miles (133 km) of frontier with China.[http://www.irrawaddy.org/archives/20470 UWSA Talks Business, Drugs Cooperation with China] === Illicit drug trade === {{See also|United Wa State Army}} Using its 30,000 personnel, the [[United Wa State Army]] (UWSA) is the largest [[narcotics trafficking]] organization in [[Southeast Asia]].{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} It was once allied with the [[Communist Party of Burma]] (4,000 soldiers). The UWSA cultivates vast areas of land for the [[opium]] [[Poppy (flower)|poppy]], which is later refined to [[heroin]]. [[Methamphetamine]] trafficking is also important to the economy of the Wa State.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-myanmar-wa-idUSKCN1270R3?il=0 Myanmar's strongest ethnic armed group says drug label 'not fair'] The money from the [[opium]] is used for weapons. Although the [[Burmese government]] has begun taking measures to decrease the production of such drugs, it is an arduous task due to corruption at high levels in the government and a lack of infrastructure to carry out operations.[https://archive.is/20130128213515/http://www.mjfqw.com/bencandy.php?fid=44&id=3007 缅甸第二特区佤邦,一切好象是中国的一个延伸], 2011-10-15. In 2005, Wa State was declared by the UWSP as a drug-free zone and the cultivation of opium was prohibited.[http://www.unodc.org/pdf/myanmar/myanmar_strategic_programme_framework.pdf Myanmar Strategic Programme Framework] A BBC presentation aired on 19 November 2016 showed the burning of metamphetamine as well as a thriving trade in illegal animal parts. == See also == {{Portal|Myanmar}} * [[Wa people]] * [[Mang Lon]] == References == === Citations === {{Reflist|30em}} === Sources === * Hideyuki Takano, ''The Shore Beyond Good and Evil: A Report from Inside Burma's Opium Kingdom '' (2002, Kotan, {{ISBN|0-9701716-1-7}}) * [[Andrew Marshall (Asia journalist)|Andrew Marshall]], ''The Trouser People: a Story of Burma in the Shadow of the Empire''. London: Penguin; Washington: Counterpoint, 2002. {{ISBN|1-58243-120-5}}. * The Wa State, Burma [http://nationalstrategy.com/Portals/0/documents/Summer%202011%20NSFR/The%20Wa%20State.pdf The National Strategy Forum Review] * {{cite news |title = Wa leader: UWSA able to defend itself |url = http://www.english.panglong.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4602:wa-leader-uwsa-able-to-defend-itself&catid=85:politics&Itemid=266 |agency = Shan Herald |website = panglong.org |date = 2012-04-19 |accessdate = 2012-05-05 }} * Forbes, Andrew ; Henley, David (2011). ''Traders of the Golden Triangle''. Chiang Mai: Cognoscenti Books. ASIN: B006GMID5. * Midnight in Burma. ''Ein Roman über die Tochter eines Generals im Wa-Staat, nicht gerade historisch mit vielen historischen Fehlern, aber sehr spannend geschrieben'', Alex O'Brien. Asia Books {{ISBN|974-8303-58-6}} (2001). * Dr. Ba Nyan, [http://www.english.panglong.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4744:who-are-the-wa&catid=93:general&Itemid=291 Who are the Wa?] == External links == * [[Geographic coordinate system|Coordinates]]: {{coord|22|10|N|99|00|E|region:MM_type:adm1st_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=inline,title}} * {{zh icon}} [http://blog.sina.com.cn/u/2424587420 Wa state News Bureau] ([[Sina Blog]]) * {{smaller|{{color|dimgray|(in Standard Mandarin)}}}} [http://v.youku.com/v_show/id_XMjU2NTA3NDM2.html Television news broadcast from Wa State] * [http://www.usdoj.gov/dea/pubs/states/newsrel/nyc012405.html DEA Page] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101031100157/http://www.burmaissues.org//En/wa.html Wa - Burma Issues] [[Category:Wa people]] [[Category:Geography of Myanmar]] [[Category:Separatism in Myanmar]] [[Category:Former unrecognized countries]] [[Category:Chinese-speaking countries and territories]] [[Category:States and territories established in 1989]] [[Category:Illegal drug trade in Southeast Asia]] [[Category:Military dictatorships]] [[Category:Enclaves and exclaves]]

revision.comment: adding links to references using [[Google Scholar]]
revision.text:
{{short description|System to measure the color of water by observing the spectrum of radiation leaving the water.}} '''Water Remote Sensing''' studies the [[color of water]] through the observation of the [[spectrum]] of water leaving radiation. From the study of this spectrum, the concentration of optically active components of the upper layer of the water body can be concluded via specific [[algorithms]].<ref name="Laanen">Laanen, M.L. (2007)."[http://dare.ubvu.vu.nl/bitstream/handle/1871/10799/8066.pdf?sequence=5Jun Yellow Matters- Improving the remote sensing of Coloured Dissolved Organic Matter in inland freshwaters]" Ph.D. Thesis. Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam: The NL.</ref> [[Water quality]] monitoring by [[remote sensing]] and close-range instruments has obtained considerable attention since the founding of EU Water Framework Directive.<ref name="Laanen" /> [[File:The path covered by light from the sun through the water body to the remote sensing sensor.jpg|thumbnail|right|The path covered by light from the sun through the water body to the remote sensing sensor <ref name="Laanen" />]]
== History ==
If water remote sensing is defined as the observation of the water from a distance in order to describe its color, without taking water samples, the gradual development of understanding of the transparency of natural waters and of the reason of their clarity variability and coloration has been sketched from the times of Henry Hudson (1600) to those of Chandrasekhara Raman (1930).<ref>Marcel, R., Wernand & Winfried W.C.Gieskes (2012), "Ocean Optics from 1600 (Hudson) to 1930 (Raman) Shifting interpretation of natural water colouring", Paris, France: Union des oceanographes de France (published 1 January 2012)</ref> However, the development of water remote sensing techniques (by the use of satellite imaging, aircraft or close range optical devices) didn't start until the early 1970s. These first techniques measured the [[Electromagnetic spectrum|spectral]] and thermal differences in the emitted energy from water surfaces. In general, empirical relationships were settled between the spectral properties and the water quality parameters of the water body.<ref name="Ritchie">Ritchie, J.C; Zimba, P.V.; Everitt, J.H. (2003), “Remote Sensing Techniques to Assess Water Quality”, American Society for Photogrammetry Engineering and Remote Sensing, 69:695-704.</ref> In 1974, Ritchie et al. (1974) <ref>Ritchie, J.C.; McHenry, J.R.; Schiebe, F.R.; Wilson, R.B.(1974),“The relationship of reflected solar radiation and the concentration of sediment in the surface water of reservoirs”,Remote Sensing of Earth Resources Vol. III (F. Shahrokhi, editor),The University of Tennessee Space Institute, Tullahoma, Tennessee,3:57–72</ref> developed an empirical approach to determine suspended sediments. This kind of empirical models are only able to use to determine water quality parameters of water bodies with similar conditions. In 1992 an analytical approach was used by Schiebe et al. (1992).<ref name="Schiebe">Schiebe, F.R., Harrington, Jr., J.A.; Ritchie, J.C. (1992), “Remote sensing of suspended sediments: The Lake Chicot, Arkansas project”, International Journal of Remote Sensing, 13(8):1487–1509</ref> This approach was based on the optical characteristics of water and water quality parameters to elaborate a physically based model of the relationship between the spectral and physical properties of the surface water studied. This physically based model was successfully applied in order to estimate suspended sediment concentrations.<ref name="Ritchie" /><ref name="Schiebe" /><ref name="Harrington">Harrington, J.A., Jr., Schiebe, F.R.; Nix, J.F. (1992). “Remote sensing of Lake Chicot, Arkansas: Monitoring suspended sediments, turbidity and secchi depth with Landsat MSS”, Remote Sensing of Environment, 39(1):15–27</ref>
== Function ==
Water Remote sensing instruments allow to record the color of a water body, which provides information on the presence and abundance of optically active natural water components. The water color spectrum is defined as an apparent optical property (AOP) of the water. This means that the color of the water is influenced by the angular distribution of the light field and by the nature and quantity of the substances in the medium, in this case, water.<ref name="Sathyendranath">IOCCG (2000). Remote Sensing of Ocean Colour in Coastal, and Other Optically-Complex Waters. Sathyendranath, S. (ed.), Reports of the International Ocean-Colour Coordinating Group, No. 3, IOCCG, Dartmouth, Canada.</ref> Thus, the value of this parameter will change with changes in the optical properties and concentrations of the optically active substances in the water, the inherent optical properties or IOPS.<ref name="Laanen" /> The IOPS are independent from the angular distribution of light but they are dependent from the type and substances present in the medium as well.<ref name="Sathyendranath"/> For instance, the diffuse [[attenuation coefficient]] of downwelling irradiance, Kd (it is often used as an index of water clarity or [[ocean turbidity]]) is defined as an AOP, while the [[absorption coefficient]] and the scattering coefficient of the medium are defined as IOPS.<ref name="Sathyendranath"/> There are two different approaches to determine the concentration of optically active water components by the study of the spectra. The first approach consist of empirical algorithms based on statistical relationships and the second approach consists of analytical algorithms based on the inversion of calibrated bio-optical models.<ref name="Laanen" /><ref name="Sathyendranath"/> Accurate calibration of the relationships/models used is an important condition for successful inversion on water remote sensing techniques and the determination of concentration of water quality parameters from observed spectral remote sensing data.<ref name="Laanen" /> Thus, these techniques depend on their ability to record these changes in the spectral signature of light backscattered from water surface and relate these recorded changes to water quality parameters via empirical or analytical approaches. Depending of the water constituents of interest and the sensor used, different parts of the spectrum will be analysed.<ref name="Ritchie" />
== Contribution ==
[[File:Specific phytoplankton absorption spectra.xcf|thumbnail|right|Example of specific phytoplankton absorption spectra. In this graph the characteristic blue and red Ch-a peaks at 438 nm and 676 nm can be seen. Another visible peak is the Cyanophicocianin absorption maximum at 624 nm.<ref name="Laanen" />]]By the use of Optical close range devices (e.g. [[spectrometers]], [[radiometers]]), airplanes or helicopters (airborne remote sensing) and satellites (space born remote sensing), the light reflected from the water bodies is measured. For instance, algorithms are used to retrieve parameters such as [[chlorophyll-a]](Chl-a) and Suspended Particulate Matter (SPM) concentration, the absorption by [[colored dissolved organic matter]] at 440 nm (aCDOM) and [[secchi depth]].<ref name="Laanen" /> The measurement of these values will give an idea about the water quality of the water body being studied. A very high concentration of green pigments like chlorophyll might indicate the presence of an algal bloom, for example, due to eutrophication processes. Thus, the chlorophyll concentration could be used as a proxy or indicator for the trophic condition of a water body. In the same manner, other optical quality parameters such as suspended particles or Suspended Particulate matter (SPM), Colored Dissolved Organic Matter (CDOM), Transparency (Kd), and chlorophyll-a (Chl-a) can be used to monitor water quality.<ref name="Laanen" />
== References ==
{{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.eulakes.eu/servizi/notizie/notizie_homepage.aspx/ EULAKES project, water quality by remote sensing technique] * [http://www.coastcolour.org/ CoastColour project: remote sensing of the coastal zone] * [http://www.brockmann-consult.de/revamp/ Revamp project: Regional Validation of MERIS Chlorophyll products in North Sea Coastal Waters] * [http://www.geo.mtu.edu/great_lakes/lakersi/cgi-bin/rsi_kitie/template1.html/ The Great Lakes Web Site: Michigan Tech's Large Lakes Remote Sensing program] * [http://www.coastwatch.msu.edu/ CoastWatch project] * [http://www.ioccg.org/ International Ocean Colour Coordinating Group] * [http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Observing_the_Earth/ ESA European Space Agency activities: Observing the earth] * [http://oceancolor.gsfc.nasa.gov/ Ocean Color Web] * [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S004896971100444X/ Assessing remotely sensed chlorophyll-a for the implementation of the Water Framework Directive in European perialpine lakes]
